title: Rosenbaum's Causal Identification Theorem
contentHtml: Rosenbaum's theorem provides a framework for identifying causal effects in observational studies.

theorem.statement:
\[\text{If }P(y_1, y_0 | x, z) \text{ is a causal model for the treatment effect, then}\] 
\[\text{there exists a propensity score }e(x) \text{ such that }Y_i(1) = E[Y | X=x, Z=1]\]
theorem.proofSketch: The proof involves showing that the propensity score can be used to reweight the data to mimic an experiment.

intuition: This theorem provides a way to identify causal effects in observational studies by using the propensity score to adjust for confounding variables.
realWorldApplications: Estimating the effect of a new marketing campaign on sales
